section.title: Introduction
section.para: Android is a mobile phone and embedded device operating system developed by the Open Handset Alliance. It is based on a Linux kernel with a virtual machine environment for managed code application.

The main application development environment is based on Java bytecode, that is transformed into dalvik executable code optimized for the constrained devices. Java is the default programming language and the API's are all Java based.

section.title: Configuring Build Environment for Android Development
section.para:
Android
configuring build environment Before you attempt to build your Android libraries and applications with Maven, you will need to complete two configuration tasks:

listitem.para: Installing the Android API jar files into local or remote Maven repository
Optionally configure Maven for simplified usage of the Maven Android Plugin

section.title: Installing the Android SDK
section.para: The Maven Android Plugin relies on the presence of the Android SDK on the development environment and the ANDROID_HOME environment variable to point to the installation location. The SDK should be installed following the directions on the Android Developer web site athttp://developer.android.com/sdk/index.html.

In addition to the SDK itself the various platform versions or API levels should be installed as part of the install. Instruction for this process are located at http://developer.android.com/sdk/adding-components.html. Depending on the target platform version of the application you can install a subset of platforms or just go ahead and install all available versions.

For the usage of the Maven Android Plugin the ANDROID_HOME environment variable needs to point to the folder where the SDK is installed. For example if the SDK is installed in /opt/android-sdk-linux this can be achieved with export ANDROID_HOME=/opt/android-sdk-linux in Unix/bash based systems or set ANDROID_HOME=/opt/android-sdk-linux in Windows systems.
Optionally the path ANDROID_HOME/tools can be added to the PATH variable to allow easy command line execution of the various tools provided with the SDK.

section.title: Android artifact install into Maven repository
section.para: Once the SDK is installed you will need to provide the API jar files to Maven in a repository. The Maven Android SDK Deployer tool allows you to do that for a single machine in a local repository as well as for any number of machines in a remote repository server.

The Maven Android SDK deployer tool is available for download at http://github.com/mosabua/maven-android-sdk-deployer. Simply click on the Download Source button and extracted the downloaded zip or tar archive in a folder of your choice. A folder with a naming pattern of mosabua-maven-android-sdk-deployer-XXX with XXX some revision number like df824df will be created. Entering the sdk deployer folder with e.g. cd mosabua-maven-android-sdk-deployer-df824df readies you to install the desired artifacts.

section.title: Installation to local repository
section.para: In order to install the android API jar files from the different platform revisions into your local repository you run the command mvn clean install in the deployer tool folder. By default this will upload all android.jar and maps.jar files into repository, which is by defaulted located in ~/.m2/repository. You should find all newly installed files in the android and com/google/android/maps folders.

section.title: Installation to remote repository
section.para: The above deployment works fine for one machine, but if you need to supply a whole team of developers and a cluster of build machines with the artifacts, you will want to deploy the artifacts once to a remote repository server that is available to all users.
As a first step you will need to edit the repo.url property in the pom.xml in the top folder of the Maven Android SDK Deployer tool to point to the repository you want to publish to.

Then you need to add a server with the correct access credentials for the server to your settings.xml.
Snippet for settings.xml for the repository server access credentials
<settings> <servers> <server> <id>android.repo</id> <username>your username</username> <password>your password</password> </server> </servers> </settings>
Once that configuration is completed you can deploy the artifacts with the command mvn deploy. As a result you should find the artifact in the repository of your remote server.

section.title: Installation of a subset of all platforms
section.para: By default the Maven Android SDK Deployer tool will attempt to install or deploy all versions of the platforms artifacts into a repository. If you however decided to only install a subset of the components in the section above , the tool can be used with profile options to only install or deploy some artifacts. This can be done by specifying the platform API versions as a profile name: mvn install -P 2.1. Available profile names are 1.1, 1.5, 1.6, 2.0 and 2.1.

section.title: HelloFlashlight Example
section.para: The HelloFlashlight example application serves as a starting point to introduce you to the usage of the Maven Android Plugin. You can follow the same steps to introduce a Maven Android Plugin based build to your Android application. After the initial environment setup documented above the Android Development Tools from http://developer.android.com/sdk/eclipse-adt.html where installed and used to create a new Android project.
To enable a Maven based build of the project the following pom.xml file was added in the root folder of the project:

The main characteristics of the project file are:
the packaging type of apk
the dependency to the Android platform jar
and the build configuration with the Maven Android Plugin and the Compiler Plugin

The Android Package packaging type apk is the main hook and kicks off the life cycle modifications of the Maven Android Plugin. It takes care of all the custom calls to the various tools of the SDK that will be explained later.

The declared dependency to the android platform jar has to use the version of the target platform as published into the Maven repository by the Maven Android SDK Deployer. It in turn takes the library version from the Platform.Version and the Pkg.Revision values in the source.properties file in the respective platforms folder of the Android SDK. The current valid values are 1.1_r1,, 1.5_r3, 1.6_r2, 2.0_r1, 2.0.1_r1 and 2.1_r1. Simply browse the android folder of your maven repository/repository server to see what the versions are.

The configuration of the Maven Compiler Plugin in the build is necessary since Android uses Java 5 code with annotations and such and the Java compiler needs to know that. The main configuration of the Maven Android Plugin is done in the build section, but out of the box only limited configuration is necessary.

To build the application and run it on an already started emulator you could use mvn clean install android:deploy.
The code for the example application is available as part of the maven-android-plugin-samples available at http://code.google.com/p/maven-android-plugin/wiki/Samples.

section.title: The Maven-Android-Plugin Lifecycle
section.para:
Maven-Android-Plugin
lifecycle The Android Maven plugin customizes the lifecycle based on the packaging. If your project has a packaging of type apk the Android plugin with execute a customized lifecycle.

section.title: Android Plugin Goals
section.para:
Android
plugin goals
The Android Maven Plugin contains the following goals:

listitem.para: The apk goal creates the android package (apk) file. By default the plugin signs the file with the debug keystore. The configuration parameter sign debug false debug sign can be used to disable the signing process.

The deploy goal deploys the built apk file, or another specified apk, to a connected device or emulator. This goal is automatically performed when running through the integration-test life cycle phase on a project with instrumentation tests (e.g. mvn install or mvn integration-test).

The deploy-dependencies goal deploys all directly declared dependencies of apk in this project. This goal is usually used in a project with instrumentation tests, to deploy the apk to test onto the device before running the deploying and running the instrumentation tests apk. The goal is automatically performed when running through the integration-test life cycle phase on a project with instrumentation tests (e.g. mvn install or mvn integration-test).
The dex goal converts compiled Java classes to the Android Dalivk Executable (dex) format.
The generate-sources goal generates R.java based on the resources specified by the resources configuration parameter. It generates java files based on aidl files.

If the configuration parameter deleteConflictingFiles is true (which it is by default), this goal has also deletes any R.java files found in the source directory, deletes any .java files with the same name as an .aidl file found in the source directory and deletes any Thumbs.db files found in the resource directory.
The instrument goal runs the instrumentation android package on the device/emulator.

The internal-integration-test goal is called automatically when the lifecycle reaches the integration-test phase. It determines whether to call the goal instrument in this phase based on the existance of instrumentation test classes in the current project. The goal is internal to the plugin lifecycle and should not be used as separate invocation on the command line.

The internal-pre-integration-test goal is called automatically when the lifecycle reaches pre-integration-test phase. It determines whether to call the goals android:deploy-dependencies and android:deploy in this face and if necessary invokes them. The goal is internal to the plugin lifecycle and should not be used as separate invocation on the command line.
The pull goal can be used to copy files or directories from the device.
The pull goal can be used to copy files or directories to the device.
The undeploy goal removes the apk of the current project, or another specified apk, from the connected device.
